719742f-a.title: Manhattan: Foley Square - Pearl Street
719742f-a.text:
Foley Square (unofficially called Court House Square), east side, between Pearl (right) and Worth (left) Streets, showing the N.Y. County Court House under construction. These 4 views (taken at the same time) show that part of the building that will form the front. On the right
appears the old Board of Health Building.
July 1923.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
719742f-a.folder: Foley Square & Pearl Street, Manhattan, NY

719743f-c.title: Manhattan: Foley Square - Pearl Street
719743f-c.text:
Foley Square, east side, between Pearl and Worth Streets, showing the New York County Court House under construction. This set of 4 views shows the Pearl and Baxter Street sides. The fenced area in the foreground is the south side of Worth Street, east of Centre Street. On the right appears the old Board of Health Building. The entrance will be.through the unfinished frame work shown on the right. Centre Street at this
point forms the east side of Foley Square.
July 1923.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
719743f-c.folder: Foley Square & Pearl Street, Manhattan, NY

718562f-a.text:
Centre Street, east side, north from Pearl Street. Buildings shown across the background, are on the north side of Leonard Street, east from Centre to Baxter Streets. The 1-story building in the foreground, is used by the Child Welfare Board, and is on the north side of Worth Street, east of Centre Street. Eventually this will form the site of the N.Y. State Office Building.
September 24, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.
718562f-a.folder: Centre Street & Pearl Street, Manhattan, NY

719741f-a.title: Manhattan: Foley Square - Duane Street
719741f-a.text:
Foley Square, north from Duane Street, showing the east side of Centre Street (right) and the west side of Lafayette Street (left). Buildings of importance seen are, the Tombs, N.Y. State Building and the N.Y. County Court House.
March 14, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.
719741f-a.folder: Foley Square & Duane Street, Manhattan, NY

718561f-a.text:
Centre Street, east side, at Pearl Street, showing work in progress for the Federal Courts Building.
June 22, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
Neg. #1647
Slide #240

718554f-a.text:
Centre Street, south from and including Duane Street, to and including Park Row, showing the Municipal Building occuping [sic] the east side of this Street.  Shown in the foreground is the southern part of Foley Square, with the Federal Courts Building (under construction) on the left.  The 21 story structure partially shown on the right is the Court Square Building, No. 2 Lafayette Street.

About 1935

Gift of Dr. Michael Wishengrad, A.R.F.S.
CREDIT LINE IMPERATIVE ON ALL REPRODUCTIONS
718554f-a.folder: Centre Street & Duane Street, Manhattan, NY

719740f-a.title: Manhattan: Foley Square - Duane Street
719740f-a.text:
Foley Square, east side, north from Duane Street and showing from right to left the Federal Court Building, the N.Y. County Court House, the N.Y. State Building and the new Board of Health Building.
1936.
W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Writers Project.
719740f-a.folder: Foley Square & Duane Street, Manhattan, NY

719733f-a.text:
Foley Square: The New York County Court House on the east side of Centre Street, between Pearl and Worth Streets, as viewed northward from the stens of the Federal Courts Bldg. At the extreme left
appears a portion of the New York State Bldg.
June 12, 1938.
P. L. Sperr
719733f-a.folder: Centre Street & Pearl Street, Manhattan, NY

719750f-c.title: Manhattan: Foley Square - Pearl Street
719750f-c.text:
Foley Square, easterly side, north from Duane, across Pearl, to Worth Streets, showing respectively, The Federal Courts Bldg., the New York County Court House and the New York State Bldg. all facing on what technically is Centre Street.
Views 2 and 3 emphasize the New York County Court House and are viewed eastward from Elm Street (the westerly boundary of the square) which in its self is really a continuation of Lafayette Street.
All of these structures are built upon and around what in early days was Collect Pond and where in 1796, John Fitch tried his new steamboat under the observation of Chancellor Livingston and other prominent New Yorkers. Where Centre and Leonard Streets intersect today it had a depth of 60 feet. During the English and French conflict, President Jefferson (1807) ordered an embargo on all shipping and New York suffered. To alleviate same, individuals were set to work to fill in this pond and morass and thereby set a precedent for public work relief. A drainage canal was cut thru in 1809 which later became Canal Street.
Propositions for the use of the area as a Park were introduced as early as 1789, though naught came of them and it remained a dreary vacant area awaiting modern scientific engineering. Their main difficulty was not water but quicksand and most of these buildings have what is called a floating foundation.
June 12, 1938.
Views 1,2 and 3
P. L. Sperr
719750f-c.folder: Foley Square & Pearl Street, Manhattan, NY

718563f-c.text:
(1)

	Centre Street (right), north from but not including Pearl Street, showing (center of view) prominently the Building for the Department of Health, Hospitals and Sanitation on the north side of Worth Street, between Centre and Lafayette (left) Streets.  Also shown (right) is part of the New York State Office Building, on the east side of Centre Street, north from Worth to Leonard Streets.  The area appearing the foreground is known as Foley Square.

April 18, 1937
P. L. Sperr.

(2)

	The same, a closer view, and showing a small part on the west side of Centre Street, north from Pearl to Worth Streets; a part of the Square.
April 18, 1937
P. L. Sperr.

(3)

	The same, a more limited view.

April 18, 1937
P. L. Sperr.

(1) Duane Street, north side, east from but not including Centre Street, to and including Cardinal Place; shown in the background is the frame work of the United States Government Building, St. Andrew's Roman Catholic Church is in the foreground.
October 8, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
Neg. #1649
(2) The same, from a different angle.
October 8, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
(3) The same, at an earlier date. The 6-story building on the extreme right is No. 29 and is at the Bowery. Also seen is (left) the rear of a 4-story house and a 2-story adjunct bearing No. 2O City Hall Place, at and adjoining the N.E. corner of Duane Street.
February 24, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
